title: About Me
text:
About Me
I‚Äôm an ecologist working at the interface of invasion biology and digital conservation‚Ä¶

title: Welcome
text:
I‚Äôm an ecologist researching biological invasions, culturomics, and digital data for conservation. I use online data, species distributions, and public perception analyses to improve biodiversity policy and public awareness.
Currently, I‚Äôm developing tools to support biosecurity, horizon scanning, and public engagement with biodiversity loss.test.

AmphibiCast is an original amphibian‚Äëfocused podcast that explores science, conservation, and husbandry each week.

title: News and Media
text:
GBIF data featured in research by Susan Canavan

Assessing potential causes of bamboo invasions
Published by GBIF, 1 June 2017
This feature highlights research led by Susan Canavan on the global spread of bamboos, which used over 23,000 species occurrence records sourced via GBIF. The study revealed that human usage, particularly the cultivation of multiple cultivars, is a stronger predictor of bamboo invasions than species traits alone. Traits like rhizome type, culm height, and diameter also correlated with introduction likelihood. The findings underscore the central role of human agency in shaping invasion risk.

Citation: Canavan S, Richardson DM, Visser V, Roux JJL, Vorontsova MS, Wilson JRU (2016) The global distribution of bamboos: assessing correlates of introduction and invasion. AoB Plants DOI:10.1093/aobpla/plw078

title: News and Media
section: Global biodiversity platforms in invasion science
text:
Global biodiversity platforms in invasion science
Mongabay Wildtech interviews Susan Canavan

GBIF open-source species location data supports global biodiversity analyses
Mongabay Wildtech, 31 July 2017
In an article on the power of open-access data platforms like GBIF, Susan Canavan discusses how digitized biodiversity records are indispensable for invasion biology. Her comments reflect on the challenges of curating global datasets and the importance of database cleaning for large taxonomic groups. The piece also includes perspectives from researchers around the world who use GBIF to model distributions and understand impacts of invasive species, land-use, and climate change.

‚ÄúEstablishing up-to-date inventories of taxa and their distribution is fundamental for invasion science.‚Äù ‚Äì S. Canavan

The article showcases Susan‚Äôs research on bamboo distribution and includes photographs of field and herbarium work, emphasizing the importance of digitized records and collaborative infrastructures for advancing conservation.

title: News and Media
text:
1 June 2017 ‚Äî GBIF Feature
I worked with colleagues to explore how bamboo species have spread globally and what drives those introductions. We used more than 23,000 records from GBIF and found that while certain biological traits matter, the strongest driver of invasion is human use.

title: News and Media
text:
31 July 2017 ‚Äî Mongabay Wildtech
In this Mongabay article, I discussed the value of open biodiversity data like GBIF for global ecological research. I shared insights from my bamboo study, the challenges of working with large datasets, and why open-access platforms are essential for tracking biological invasions.

‚ÄúEstablishing up-to-date inventories of taxa and their distribution is fundamental for invasion science.‚Äù

üîó Read the article on Mongabay

title: Susan Canavan, PhD
text:
I worked with colleagues to explore how bamboo species spread around the world ‚Äî and what drives those introductions. We used over 23,000 species records from GBIF to map global bamboo distributions and found that species with more cultivars and certain traits (like culm height and rhizome type) were more likely to be introduced. But above all, it was clear that human use ‚Äî not just biology ‚Äî was the primary driver of invasion.
 Read the full GBIF feature ‚Üí













In an interview with Mongabay Wildtech, I talked about the role of open-source biodiversity platforms like GBIF in supporting large-scale research. My bamboo project relied on global occurrence data that would have been impossible to collect independently. I also shared some of the practical challenges of working with big datasets ‚Äî like cleaning coordinates and resolving taxonomic issues ‚Äî and why those hurdles are worth it for the insights they unlock.
 Read the full article on Mongabay ‚Üí

title: News and Media
text:
1 June 2017






I worked with colleagues to explore how bamboo species spread around the world ‚Äî and what drives those introductions.
We used over 23,000 species records from GBIF to map global bamboo distributions and found that species with more cultivars and certain traits (like culm height and rhizome type) were more likely to be introduced.
But above all, it was clear that human use ‚Äî not just biology ‚Äî was the primary driver of invasion.
